details.title: Optimum Bivariate Step-Stress Accelerated Life Test for Censored Data
details.standardTitle: Optimum Bivariate Step-Stress Accelerated Life Test for Censored Data

p: Chenhua Li was born in China. She received the Bachelor's degree of Engineering in Industrial Automation from Zhejiang University, China, in 1998. She obtained her Master's degree of Management in Business Management from Tianjin University, China, in 2001. Currently she is a Ph.D. candidate in the Department of Mechanical and Industrial Engineering, Northeastern University, Boston, Massachusetts. Her current research interests include reliability and life testing, optimization algorithms, quality control, and applied statistics.

authors.affiliation: Dept. of Mech. & Ind. Eng., Northeastern Univ., Boston, MA
authors.name: Chenhua Li

p: Nasser Fard received his Ph.D. in Systems Engineering from the University of Arizona in 1982. He served as a faculty of Industrial Engineering at Wichita State University prior to joining the faculty of the Mechanical and Industrial Engineering Department at Northeastern University. He served as an associate editor of the IEEE Transactions on Reliability, and he has been on the editorial board of the International Journal of Reliability, Quality and Safety Engineering. Dr. Fard's experience, and most recent research and professional activities are in Reliability and Maintainability Analysis, Design and Analysis of Experiments, Reliability Modeling and Evaluation of Network Communication Systems, and stochastic modeling. He has been principal investigator for public and private research projects, and consultant to many organizations on Quality and Reliability related problems.

authors.affiliation: Dept. of Mech. & Ind. Eng., Northeastern Univ., Boston, MA
authors.name: Nasser Fard

details.abstract: A step-stress accelerated life test for two stress variables is developed. The time to failure follows the Weibull distribution, and the test is subject to termination at a predetermined time, leading to censored failure data. An optimum test plan is developed to determine the test interval for each combination of stress levels. The scale parameter of the Weibull distribution for each combination of stress levels is defined as a log linear function of the stress levels. The optimal criterion is defined to minimize the asymptotic variance of the maximum likelihood estimator of the life for a specified reliability

kwd: optimum bivariate step-stress accelerated life testing

citations.title: Optimum Bivariate Step-Stress Accelerated Life Test for Censored Data

links.abstract: Optimal times of changing stress-level for the simple step-stress plans under the Khamis-Higgins model (an alternative to the Weibull step-stress model) are determined for a wide range of values of the model parameters. The applicability of the "optimal time of changing stress" formula obtained by Khamis-Higgins for a known shape parameter to the case of unknown shape parameter is examined. Their formula provides a reasonable approximation to the actual optimal times of changing stress levels wi...

context.text: Alhadeeded & Yang [1] obtained the optimal design for the simple SSALT using the KH model assuming complete test data, without any censoring.

references.title:
Optimal simple step-stress plan for Khamis-Higgins
model
references.text: A. A. Alhadeed, S. S. Yang, "Optimal simple step-stress plan for Khamis-Higgins model", IEEE Trans. Reliability, vol. 51, no. 2, pp. 212-215, 2002.

links.abstract: The authors present the optimum simple time-step and failure-step stress accelerated life tests for the case where a prespecified censoring time is involved. An exponential life distribution with a mean that is a log-linear function of stress, and a cumulative exposure model are assumed. The authors obtain the optimum test plans to minimize the asymptotic variance of the maximum-likelihood estimator of the mean life at a design stress. Nomographs for the optimum time-step stress test are also gi...

context.text: Bai & Kim & Lee [2] extended the results of Millers & Nelson [7] to the case of considering censored failure data.

references.title:
Optimum simple step-stress accelerated life
tests with censoring
references.text: D. S. Bai, M. S. Kim, S. H. Lee, "Optimum simple step-stress accelerated life tests with censoring", IEEE Trans. Reliability, vol. 38, no. 5, pp. 528-532, 1989.

links.abstract: Optimum simple step-stress accelerated life testing plans have practical limitations. They highly depend upon the assumption of a linear relationship between stress and time-to-failure and use only two extreme stresses that can cause irrelevant failure modes. Thus, 3-step plans are preferable. In this paper, the authors derive the optimum quadratic plan and propose and evaluate a 3-step test plan, the compound linear, as an alternative to the optimum simple step-stress plan and optimum quadratic...

context.text: Khamis & Higgins [3] considered a quadratic stress-life relation, and derived the optimum 3-step SSALT for the exponentially distributed type I censored data.

references.title: Optimum 3-step step-stress tests
references.text: I. H. Khamis, J. J. Higgins, "Optimum 3-step step-stress tests", IEEE Trans. Reliability, vol. 45, no. 2, pp. 341-345, 1996.

context.text: Khamis [4] proposed an optimal m-step SSALT design with k stress variables, assuming an exponential life distribution, and complete knowledge of the stress-life relation with multiple stress variables.

references.title: Optimum M-step design with K stress variables
references.text: I. H. Khamis, "Optimum M-step design with K stress variables", Communications in Statistics: Simulation & Computation, vol. 26, no. 4, pp. 1301-1313, 1997.

links.abstract: The mathematical intractability of the Weibull cumulative exposure model (CE-M) has impeded the development of statistical procedures for step-stress accelerated life tests. Our new model (KH-M) is based on a time transformation of the exponential CE-M. The time-transformation enables the reliability engineer to use known results for multiple-step, multiple-stress models that have been developed for the exponential step-stress model. KH-M has a realistically appealing proportional-hazard propert...

context.text: Khamis & Higgins [5] proposed a time transformation of the exponential CE model for analyzing Weibull SSALT data, which is called the KH model.

references.title: A new model for step-stress testing
references.text: I. H. Khamis, J. J. Higgins, "A new model for step-stress testing", IEEE Trans. Reliability, vol. 47, no. 2, pp. 131-134, 1998.

links.abstract: This paper describes a model for multiple stress-type accelerated life data. In addition, the use of an algorithm, which was specifically developed for this model is illustrated. The model is based on the widely known log-linear model (1990) and is formulated for the Weibull and lognormal distributions for a variety of censoring schemes using likelihood theory. An algorithm has been developed for the solution of this model, and implemented in a recently released software package, ALTA Pro/sup TM...

context.text: Other studies have also considered more than one stress variable [6], [12].
Mettas [6] illustrated similar experimental data for a typical three stress type constant-stress accelerated life test.
The following example uses the experimental data of Mettas [6] for the two stress variables (temperature and voltage) to obtain the initial estimates of the unknown parameters.
Then the log-linear model with constant shape parameter was used: and the best fit values for the parameters were obtained as [6] .

references.title:
Modeling & analysis for multiple stress-type
accelerated life data
references.text: A. Mettas, "Modeling & analysis for multiple stress-type accelerated life data", Proceedings of Annual Reliability and Maintainability Symposium, pp. 138-143, 2000.

links.abstract: This paper presents optimum plans for simple (two stresses) step-stress tests where all units are run to failure. Such plans minimize the asymptotic variance of the maximum likelihood estimator (MLE) of the mean life at a design stress. The life-test model consists of: 1) an exponential life distribution with 2) a mean that is a log-linear function of stress, and 3) a cumulative exposure model for the effect of changing stress. Two types of simple step-stress tests are considered: 1) a time-step...

context.text: Miller & Nelson [7] presented the optimum simple SSALT plans assuming exponentially distributed failure time without early termination.
Bai & Kim & Lee [2] extended the results of Millers & Nelson [7] to the case of considering censored failure data.

references.title:
Optimum simple step-stress plans for accelerated
life testing
references.text: R. Miller, W. Nelson, "Optimum simple step-stress plans for accelerated life testing", IEEE Trans. Reliability, vol. R-32, no. 1, pp. 59-65, 1983.

links.abstract: This paper presents statistical models and methods for analyzing accelerated life-test data from step-stress tests. Maximum likelihood methods provide estimates of the parameters of such models, the life distribution under constant stress, and other information. While the methods are applied to the Weibull distribution and inverse power law, they apply to many other accelerated life test models. These methods are illustrated with step-stress data on time to breakdown of an electrical insulation.

context.text: Nelson [8] defined the cumulative exposure (CE) model, assuming that the remaining life of specimens depends only on the current cumulative failure probability, and the current stress, regardless of how the probability is accumulated.

references.title:
Accelerated life testing—Step-stress
models and data analysis
references.text: W. Nelson, "Accelerated life testing—Step-stress models and data analysis", IEEE Trans. Reliability, vol. R-29, no. 2, pp. 103-108, 1980.

context.text: For example, an accelerated life test of capacitors could include temperature, and voltage as two accelerated variables [9].

references.title: Accelerated Testing: Statistical Models, Test Plans, and Data Analysis
references.text: W. Nelson, Accelerated Testing: Statistical Models Test Plans and Data Analysis, 1990, John Wiley & Sons.

context.text: Pattern search is an important class of direct search optimizers [10].
For more details on global optimization achieved from pattern search, the reader may consult [10].

references.title: An Empirical Investigation of the Global Behavior of Several Pattern Search Algorithms
references.text: D. E. Parker, An Empirical Investigation of the Global Behavior of Several Pattern Search Algorithms, 1999, Research project, Department of Mathematics, College of Williams & Mary.

context.text: Yeo & Tang [13], and Tang [11] derived an optimal multiple-step SSALT, where not only the optimal hold time under low stress but also the optimum low stress levels are determined by taking into consideration the target acceleration factor.

references.title: Chapter 24: Multiple-steps step-stress accelerated life test
references.text: L. C. Tang, "Chapter 24: Multiple-steps step-stress accelerated life test" in Handbook of Reliability Engineering, pp. 441-456, 2003, Springer Verlag.

links.abstract: The authors describe an experiment, a model, and an analytic method for on/off vs. continuous policy evaluation. The methodology was developed and verified through experimentation. An experimental life-test of small DC motors was designed and performed; it involved on/off cycling vs. continuous operation under multiple stresses. A stress-factor reliability model based on the two-parameter Weibull proportional-hazards life distribution was fitted to the data. The analysis provides an estimate of ...

context.text: Other studies have also considered more than one stress variable [6], [12].
Teng & Kolarik [12] designed & performed a constant-stressaccelerated life test on DC motors, comparing on/off cycling to continuous operation under multiple stresses.

references.title: On/off cycling under multiple stresses
references.text: N. H. Teng, W. J. Kolarik, "On/off cycling under multiple stresses", IEEE Trans. Reliability, vol. 38, no. 4, pp. 494-498, 1989.

links.abstract: A sequential approach is presented to plan a multiple-steps step-stress accelerated life test (SSALT) with type-I censoring so as to achieve a pre-specified acceleration factor. An initial optimal plan for a simple SSALT, where one not only has to determine the optimum hold-time under low stress but also the optimum low stress level, is obtained by solving a constrained nonlinear program. A backward recursion scheme generates the subsequent optimal low-stress levels and hold-times for multiple-s...

context.text: Yeo & Tang [13], and Tang [11] derived an optimal multiple-step SSALT, where not only the optimal hold time under low stress but also the optimum low stress levels are determined by taking into consideration the target acceleration factor.

references.title:
Planning step-stress life-test with a target
acceleration-factor
references.text: K. P. Yeo, L. C. Tang, "Planning step-stress life-test with a target acceleration-factor", IEEE Trans. Reliability, vol. 48, no. 1, pp. 61-67, 1999.
